name: Identity gate
description: This gate has no effect. It is sometimes used for timing.

name: Pauli-\(X\) rotation gate
description: Also known as the "bit-flip" or "NOT" gate, as it transforms \(\ket{0}\) to \(\ket{1}\) and vice versa. On the Bloch sphere, this is a rotation of \(\pi\) in the X axis.

name: Pauli-\(Y\) rotation gate
description: Maps \(\ket{0}\) to \(i\ket{1}\) and \(\ket{1}\) to \(-i\ket{0}\). On the Bloch sphere, this is a rotation of \(\pi\) in the Y axis.

name: Pauli-\(Z\) rotation gate
description: The same as an \(X\) gate followed by a \(Y\), this maps \(\ket{0}\) to itself and \(\ket{1}\) to \(-\ket{1}\). On the Bloch sphere, this is a rotation of \(\pi\) in the Z axis.

name: \(S\) phase-shift gate
description: Equivalent to half of the \(Z\) gate: a rotation of \(\pi/2\) in the Z axis.

name: \(T\) phase-shift gate
description: Equivalent to a quarter of the \(Z\) gate: a rotation of \(\pi/4\) in the Z axis.

name: \(T^\dagger\) phase-shift gate
description: The opposite of the T gate: a rotation of \(-\pi/4\) in the Z axis.

name: Controlled \(X\) gate
description: Also known as the controlled NOT gate. Will leave the target qubit alone if the control qubit is \(\ket{0}\), and perform the X gate on the target qubit (\(\ket{0}\) ↔ \(\ket{1}\)) if the control qubit is \(\ket{1}\). If the control qubit is another state, this causes entanglement.

name: Controlled \(Y\) gate
description: Will leave the target qubit alone if the control qubit is \(\ket{0}\), and perform the Y gate on the target qubit if the control qubit is \(\ket{1}\). If the control qubit is another state, this causes entanglement.

name: Controlled \(Z\) gate
description: Will leave the target qubit alone if the control qubit is \(\ket{0}\), and perform the Z gate on the target qubit if the control qubit is \(\ket{1}\). If the control qubit is another state, this causes entanglement.

name: Qubit-swap gate
description: Swaps two qubit values between registers. This does not entangle.

name: Toffoli gate
description: Also known as \(ccX\) or \(ccNOT\). Much like the \(cX\) gate, will apply the \(X\) (aka \(NOT\)) gate if both control qubits are \(\ket{1}\), with entanglement for qubits neither \(\ket{0}\) nor \(\ket{1}\)
